text:
You went to check a flat at night when it was dark, and you rang the bell and asked about the blood. The workers and the porter were confused by it. I understand how you felt back then, but you’ll drive yourself crazy like this! You’re upset about the wrongs you’ve faced, first from fate and then from the police. You’re rushing around trying to get answers because you’re tired of all this suspicion and nonsense. Am I right? I can sense how you feel. But if you keep this up, you’ll lose your mind, and Razumihin will too. He’s a good guy and your stress could affect him. I’ll explain more when you’re feeling better. But please, sit down. You look terrible; just rest.

Raskolnikov sat down. He wasn’t shaking anymore, but he felt hot all over. He listened carefully to Porfiry Petrovitch, who still looked worried and friendly. Raskolnikov didn’t believe what he said, even though he wanted to. Porfiry’s surprising comment about the flat shocked him. “How does he know about the flat?” he thought suddenly. “And he’s telling me himself!” 

“Yes, in our legal work, we had a case that was very similar, a case of strange psychology,” Porfiry continued quickly. “A man confessed to murder and kept insisting he did it! It was like a hallucination; he presented facts, he...”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov's mental state deteriorates as he grapples with guilt and paranoia following a murder he feels partly responsible for.
